text:
We all know that scaling stakes on a profitable system is one the most difficult tasks to get right..
So if you applied a staking system (to a known profitable system), whereby the stakes were derived as a percentage of liability of the bank, wouldn't it  eventually find its own optimum stakes level?
Ie if the market could take the size of stakes it would steadily increase and conversely once the stakes got too big and the profits stalled or dropped, the stakes sizes would drop accordingly.
Any thoughts? Thanks

elements.text:
We all know that scaling stakes on a profitable system is one the most difficult tasks to get right..
So if you applied a staking system (to a known profitable system), whereby the stakes were derived as a percentage of liability of the bank, wouldn't it  eventually find its own optimum stakes level?
Ie if the market could take the size of stakes it would steadily increase and conversely once the stakes got too big and the profits stalled or dropped, the stakes sizes would drop accordingly.
Any thoughts? Thanks

text: HI, So in this case it is a back system. Initial stakes were just £2 to start as as a proof of concept. After a thousand of so bets, I removed the obvious things that weren't working. Stakes now, £2+ 1% of the increase in bank. So takes have risen to circa £3.78. Im inclined just to let it run and see what happens, just as an experiment. (This isnt one of my main systems, something completely different to my tried and tested systems) . I just thought it would be interesting to gain others views. This is the P&L graph

text: Think of it like this: suppose you were to find the optimal EV. In that case you d constantly earn more money and by that constantly increase the percentage converging towards infinity

text: Thanks for your thoughts. So in a real world example like this, how would you go about increasing stakes (I know the number of bets is still quite low)...but just interested.

elements.text: Thanks for your thoughts. So in a real world example like this, how would you go about increasing stakes (I know the number of bets is still quite low)...but just interested.

text: if you want to automate it, you could take your pnl over a period of time (or calculated EV) and then slightly increase stake. If this resulted in higher EV -> more stake or if lower EV -> less stake

elements.text: if you want to automate it, you could take your pnl over a period of time (or calculated EV) and then slightly increase stake. If this resulted in higher EV -> more stake or if lower EV -> less stake

text: like, always have it decide after 1 week (or what ever time period) decide if it should increase given its performance or decrease

elements.text: like, always have it decide after 1 week (or what ever time period) decide if it should increase given its performance or decrease

text: more general, if EV increases, keep the same direction (lower or higher), if it decreases, change direction

elements.text: more general, if EV increases, keep the same direction (lower or higher), if it decreases, change direction

text: Yes it is 1fully automated. If the new stakes size is recalculated after every race, then would it not act in a similar way as you describe? (my thoughts were that of you you applied it to a profitable system, and stakes just kept on increasing, then you would have a PnL graph similar to an upside down U (parabola) and that the stakes were optimal just before the graph started to level off?

elements.text: Yes it is 1fully automated. If the new stakes size is recalculated after every race, then would it not act in a similar way as you describe? (my thoughts were that of you you applied it to a profitable system, and stakes just kept on increasing, then you would have a PnL graph similar to an upside down U (parabola) and that the stakes were optimal just before the graph started to level off?

text: you would get an upside down parabola if stakes where to just increase, where the y-value would be your bank and its derivative would be your income. At the highers point of the parabola you would have your highest bank, but an EV of 0 (as the derivative at the extrema is 0)

text:
<@UQL0QDEKA> have you not heard of Martingale? :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
Seriously though, fractional Kelly is the way forward. Rather than using the _actual_ bank for calculating, I would use a fixed bank size and update daily/weekly/every 1000 bets/whatever.

elements.text: have you not heard of Martingale?
Seriously though, fractional Kelly is the way forward. Rather than using the
actual
bank for calculating, I would use a fixed bank size and update daily/weekly/every 1000 bets/whatever.

text: Kelly is for optimising your bankroll whereas you will hit market capacity issues (is this inplay?) As you know it won’t take much for your pnl to fall very fast in which case you won’t optimise your profit but just oscillate between profit and loss as it tries to stabilise but this should be simple to model
